message_1:
Here is a precise numerical problem for a math student to solve from the subtopic of Data Mining in Statistics:

In a data set, 100 observations were recorded. The mean of the data set was found to be 25, and the standard deviation was 5. Calculate the Z-score of an observation that is equal to 32.
message_2:
To calculate the Z-score of an observation, we use the following formula:

Z = (X - μ) / σ

where:
Z = Z-score
X = the observation value (in this case, 32)
μ = the mean of the data set (in this case, 25)
σ = the standard deviation of the data set (in this case, 5)

Plugging in the values, we get:

Z = (32 - 25) / 5
Z = 7 / 5
Z = 1.4

So, the Z-score of the observation with a value of 32 is 1.4.
